contentrichtext.text: '''Vincent Bourne''', familiarly known as '''Vinny Bourne''' (1695, [[Westminster]] â€“ December 2, 1747) was an [[England|English]] classical scholar. ==Life== He was the son of Andrew Bourne of [[Westminster]]. In 1710 he became a scholar at [[Westminster School]], and in 1714 entered [[Trinity College, Cambridge]]. He graduated in 1717, and obtained a fellowship three years later.<ref>{{Venn|id=BN714V|name=Bourne, Vincent}}</ref> Of his later life little is known: for most of it he was an usher at Westminster school. ==Works== During his lifetime he published three editions of his [[Latin]] poems, and in 1772 there appeared a [[quarto]] volume containing all Bourne's pieces, but also some that did not belong to him. The Latin poems are, a number of them, translations of English poems. [[William Cowper|Cowper]], an old pupil of Bourne's, [[James Beattie (writer)|James Beattie]], and [[Charles Lamb (writer)|Charles Lamb]], praised of his power of Latin versification. An edition (1840) of his ''Poemata'' has a memoir by [[John Mitford (clergyman)|John Mitford]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{1911}} {{Authority control|VIAF=69757731}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Bourne, Vincent | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1695 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = December 2, 1747 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bourne, Vincent}} [[Category:1695 births]] [[Category:1747 deaths]] [[Category:British classical scholars]] [[Category:People educated at Westminster School, London]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]]
